1.q_string: Find the ratio of acceleration due to gravity '\(g\)' at depth '\(d\)' and at height '\(h\)', where \(d=2 h\).
Two identical objects of mass m each are hung from a balance whose scale pans differ in vertical height by \(h\). What is the error in weighing in terms of density of Earth \(\rho\)?

The acceleration due to gravity on a planet 'A' is \(9\) times the acceleration due to gravity on another planet 'B'. A man jumps to a height of \(2 m\) on the surface of 'A'. How high will the same person jump on planet 'B'?
If the distance between the Sun and the Earth is \(r\), then the angular momentum of Earth around the Sun is proportional to:
If the distance between Earth and the sun becomes \(4\) times as much, then the time period of revolution will become:
If Earth is \(\frac{1}{4} t h\) of its present distance from the sun, what would be the duration of a year?
Two solid spheres of radii \(r\) and \(2r\), made of the same material, are kept in contact. The mutual gravitational force of attraction between them is proportional to:

A rocket is fired from Earth to the Moon. The distance between Earth and the Moon is r and the mass of Earth is 81 times the mass of the Moon. The gravitational force on the rocket will be zero when its distance from the Moon is:

\(\pi GM / L ^{2}\) perpendicular to the line joining the ends
\(2 \pi GM / L ^{2}\) along the line joining the ends

1.q_string: A thin wire of length \(L\) and mass \(M \)is bent to form a semicircle. What is the magnitude of the gravitational field at the centre?
Two bodies of masses \(m\) and \(M\) are placed at a distance \(d\) apart. The gravitational potential at the position where the gravitational field due to them is zero is:

Infinite number of masses, each of mass \(m\), are placed along a straight line at distances \(r, 2 r, 4 r, 8 r,\) etc. from a reference point \(O\). The gravitational field intensity at point \(O\) will be:
In case of a spherical shell having radius \(R\) and mass \(M\), which of the following graphs between gravitational intensity and distance is true?

The escape velocity of a body on Earth's surface is \(v _{ e }\). A body is thrown with a speed \(3 v _{ e }\). Assuming that the sun and the planets do not influence the motion of the body, its speed at infinity will be:
The escape velocity from the Earth is \(v _{ e }\). What is the escape velocity from a planet whose radius is twice that of the Earth and mean density the same as that of the Earth?

If a satellite is stopped suddenly in its orbit and allowed to fall freely into Earth, what is the speed with which it hits the surface of Earth? (Given: Height of the orbit from Earth's surface \(= R\))
